Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Resolving centennial- to millennial-scale trends in glacier extent and lake sedimentation in the Brooks Range, Arctic Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this collaborative project to reconstruct late Quaternary climate and glacier change in Arctic Alaska, one of few regions in the Arctic where mountain glaciers have left physical records of their former extent, making it valuable for comparing the timing and extent of mountain glacier variability between the lower latitudes and the Arctic. Several features of the climate and glacier history of the Brooks Range contrast with those from the North Atlantic region (which is often taken to represent the entire Northern Hemisphere in records of climate change) and currently available evidence indicates that the history of the Brooks Range more closely resembles glacier records from the southern Hemisphere. The investigators propose to develop records of climate change from lake sediments and records of glacier fluctuations using proglacial lake sediments and beryllium-10 dating of glacial features to address questions centered around four intervals of pronounced global change: (1) Last Glacial Maximum: Did glaciers retreat and temperatures increase in Arctic Alaska during the global LGM, as has been simulated by climate models? (2) Deglaciation: To what extent did climate change in Arctic Alaska coincide with North Atlantic climate fluctuations during deglaciation? (3) Holocene Glaciation: What was the extent of glaciers during (a) the Holocene thermal maximum, and (b) Neoglaciation? (4) Little Ice Age: Was it wetter or drier in the Brooks Range? The research will take place in suitable valleys (floatplane accessible valley with extant glaciers) in the north­central Brooks Range. The project has several educational components, including support four graduate students and several undergraduate students and visits to the community of Anaktuvuk Pass to deliver presentations on climate research and the Brooks Range. The proposed research aims to produce well-dated and quantitative records of glacier and climate variability in the northernmost glaciated region of the U.S. Documenting the past behavior of arctic glaciers when subject to extreme climate events during the late glacial period and warm intervals like the Holocene can provide valuable insight to help better predict responses to future change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With almost every year on Earth being the warmest ever recorded, climate scientists are striving to understand regional manifestations of “global” warming. In particular, the Arctic is warming two to three times faster than the planet on average. In turn, dramatic changes in the Arctic, such as sea ice loss and melting of glaciers, affect the entire planet by means of global energy balance and sea level rise. For this project, investigators from the University at Buffalo are putting this rapid Arctic climate change into a longer-term context. They reconstructed changes in glacier activity during pre-historic time periods of rapid climate change in Arctic Alaska. The investigators used geological field methods, isotopic dating tools and satellite data to determine the history of past glacier change in the Brooks Range.

 

The investigators have made several significant discoveries. One regards the precise timing of when glaciers began to retreat from their maximum positions during the last Ice Age.  When scientists compile the time of glacier maximum and subsequent retreat from across the planet, which isn’t the same from place to place, a pattern emerges that reveals regional variation of the climate system. In Arctic Alaska for example, glaciers retreated from their maximum position relatively early compared to other locations, suggesting that subtle changes in the increase of energy from the sun may have had strong effects in the Arctic. A second discovery regards the pace of glacier retreat during the last (natural) period of global warming between 19,000 and 11,000 years ago.  The data from this project showed an exceptional period of glacier recession between 16,000 and 15,000 years ago. The timing of this profound episode of glacier retreat led the investigators to conclude that Arctic Alaska behaves differently than elsewhere around the globe, and it may relate to inter-hemispheric linkages related to dramatic changes in ocean circulation.  Finally, yet one more discovery revealed that in more recent times, glaciers were advancing and reaching their pre-industrial maximum position long ago, as early as ~4500 years ago. This is unusual – most glaciers reached their pre-industrial maximum positions about 500 years ago.  The investigators concluded that changing moisture sources, perhaps related to expanding sea ice in the Arctic Ocean, may influence glacier behavior in Arctic Alaska.

 

Two graduate students and two undergraduate students participated in this research. The students wrote their graduate theses based on different components of the study; much of the thesis work was presented at conferences and published in journal articles. The principle investigators gave talks to the public about their findings, including to a native community in northern Alaska.
